sp.p: I have promis'd that you shall not be seen by him, and what I have promis'd I will perform. But, in troth, I am sorry such a man as he is your Enemy, for in troth he is a very worthy person.

sp.speaker: Bull jun.
sp.p: Why, faith, Madam, the man is what they call an honest man, and that is all but a strange humoursom, obstinate, old scoundrel, and a paultry Cit, the Devil take me, to boot.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: But, Sir, how comes a man of your quality, so familiar with a Cit, as to quarrel with him.

sp.speaker: Bull jun.
sp.p: Why, you must know, Madam, he has a Son who is a very pretty Gentleman, and one for whom I have a greater kindness than I have for any one, excepting your Daughter: And I have wonder'd a hundred times how, so very a Bear as the Father, could get so witty, so gallant a person as the Son: I suppose he had help, and some interloping Courtier slyly came in for his snacks. And yet the Monster his Father uses him like a Dog, for which I hate him, and for which I have sworn not to come n • ar him, when I can at any time avoid him.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: (apart to Frowzy) Madam, Madam, Mr Belvil gives you notice, that the old man will be here immediately, and desires that you would be prepar'd to receive him. He bids me tell you that Collonel Medley has half fox'd him.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Gad • s my life, how unlucky's this! Well, and Baldernoe?

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: Bald. sends word that he • ll be behind him but a quarter of an hour at the farthest. He sent word by the Messenger that the Engines are ready, and all things prepar'd for a general assault.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Very good! Sir, Sir, (to Bull j.) the enemy approaches, and you had best in time make good your retreat. If you have a mind to wait upon my Daughter, here's one shall conduct you. I'll follow you in a moment, and see what I can do for you.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Madam, you oblige me eternally.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: In troth, Su • y, this is hard fortune, to be bilk'd of thy Bubble when thou hadst taken so much pains in the working him up. If the old man had staid but a quarter of an hour longer, in all likelihood Friskit had been coupled▪ and the Fop had been sped. If any thing should retard the old fellow, this blessed match shall go on. But in taking all this pains with the Son, I have laid in for the deceiving the Father too: for if he disco ••• the Sons design▪ the Fop will infallibly boast of his acquaintance in France with us, and the consequence of that cannot but be to our advantage. But if there 〈…〉 likelihood of such a discovery, I must prevent it, and must discover first; make the old fellow a false and a half confidence; and concealing the name of his Son, communicate the rest of the affair as a secret to him, upon which I shall beg his advice; make him acquainted with my false fears, and my pretended jealousies; inform him of the attempts which are made upon my Daughter, but at the same time conceal the temptations and the encouragements which I industriously give underhand to them.

div.l: Thus will I cheat him, as the marry'd Jilt
From the suspecting Cuckold hides her guilt:
First she the Gallants lewd design reveals,
Then to the secret Assignation steals.
div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: A Table and Chairs. Bull sen. Frowzy, Gregory.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: MAdam, 'tis the very best in the three Kingdoms. Here, Sirrah, take the Key of my Closet, and bring the two quart Bottle of Brandy to the Countess. I wonder his Lordship is not come yet.

sp.speaker: Frowzy.
sp.p: I expect him every moment: He sent word that he would come in the dusk, and come mystically. Indeed all that he does is done in the dusk, and mystically. Oh 'tis a very mysterious person!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nay, Gadsooks, they all say he is a great person, and has more out of the way Politicks than any man in the three Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Frowz
sp.p: Oh! quite another sort of a thing from your clumsy awkward Brittish Politician: He has often a whole Intrigue in one single grimace, and his jests and his frolicks are all of them master-pieces of State.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
Frowz.
sp.p: Ay, poor Creature, she wants it.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Faith and troth I am sorry to hear she's so ill. Sirrah, fill to her Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Mr. Bull, on the other side of the water this liquor is grown mightily in use among women of my quality. Do they use it here?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud, Madam, they drink nothing else; formerly, saving your Ladyships presence, only Bawds drank Brandy, but now the poor Jades can't go to the price of it; and as some great Ladies have taken their trade out of their hands, they have taken their liquor.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: But did the Coll. acquaint you, say you, with the misfortune which my Daughter met with in France?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: He told me she was deeply in love with a Gentleman, who left her in the height of her passion, and came for England. Does your Ladyship mind the Colour of that Brandy?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: A lovely Complexion indeed!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: And the young Lady saw the very person as she was coming to my house?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Ay, just at the corner of Bow-street.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: And the sight renew'd her disorder?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: To both our sorrows, God knows.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: How does your Ladyship like the flavour?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: A most alluring flavour, in truth. Come, Sir, my Daughters Health to you.

Upon my honour this is right Nantz: I warrant this costs you ten and eight pence a Gallon at least. At the last Conference that I had abroad for the publick benefit, there was some quantity of it drunk; since I have tasted nothing like it: As Gad shall judge me, this is a treasure.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Your Ladyship is a true and nice Judge.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Nay, tho I say it, for Politicks—

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: And Brandy—

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p:
There is no woman alive comes near me. But still I forget my dear Child. Oh Lord! Mr.
• ull, I mightily want your advice. At least I would have him think so (aside.) For, as Mr. Belvil says, people never believe we are so sincere as when we flatter them most.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why, look you Madam, if the Lady's condition is so desperate, the Gentleman must be told that she loves him.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Ah God, Sir, he knew it in France.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: And did not love her again?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Oh! Doted on her •

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What, and left her?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: The old whimsical Fop his Father would have it so.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Then it is his Estate concerning which you have a mind to be satisfy'd. Your Ladyship has reason: For your Daughter has thirty thousand pound. Bless me, what a Fortune there is! And your Ladyship can encrease it considerably out of your own Joynture. which I know to be three thousand a year.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: And pray Sir who gave you this information?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Tho I never had the honour to see your Ladyship nor your Daughter before, yet I am acquaintwith the circumstances of every considerable person in the Kingdom. It is partly my Trade, Madam.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Then the Gentleman about whom I enquire •

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Tell me but his name, and I'll tell you his Estate immediately.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p:
I make no enquiry after his Estate. Shall I stand upon a little dirt, when my dear Childs life is at stake? The thing that I want to be satisfy'd of, is
whether he is a person of quality: For I'll see her dye a thousand times rather than she shall marry a filthy little fellow.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Could your Ladyship be so cruel as to see her die rather?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: To see her die! Ay, to see her damn'd rather.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Oh Lord! oh Lord! damn'd.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Ay, damn'd. I mean in an honourable way, Mr. Bull, and as a woman of quality should be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: How does your Ladyship call the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Mr. Dorant.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Mr. Dorant?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Dorant, Son to Viscount Dorant.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud, I never heard either of the name or the title.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: That's strange, he says he knows you very well; and has lately had a quarrel with you, for your severity against your Son.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, where is he to be found?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Herein your House.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: In my house?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Ay, he is at present with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: With your Ladyships leave, I'll go talk with him immediately.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Sir, by no means he has sworn not to see you, by reason of the foresaid quarrel, and I have promis'd him that he should not.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud, Madam, your Ladyship is abus'd. This is some Rogue, some Cheat, some Fortune-hunter.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: It is impossible, he does not look like any such man.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Madam, those vermin swarm, and multiply as fast in this itching Age, as Rats do at Sea in a Ship laden with Salt.

sp.speaker: Bull jun.
sp.p: This damn'd Father of mine won't be gone, and the time presses. If I can steal out while his back's turn'd, the young Lady has promis'd to follow.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: (spying Bull jun.) So Friskit has follow'd my instructions and sent him out, for he behaves himself so extravagantly, that he would certainly discover himself, and therefore I resolved to discover him first. Mr Dorrant. your Servant.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (turning about) Bless my Eyes! What do I see! Gadsbud I am giddy, my head turns round. Madam, is this the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: The Gentleman! Why don't you know him then?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Oh extremely well! Mr Dorant! Sweet Sir your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: (aside) I am discover'd. Impudence assist me. Honest Bull! How dost thou do? Stairing him in the face, and shaking him by the hand.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (aside) Oh horrible insolence! oh prodigy of impudence!

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: (aside) I am sure it is none of my business to be at this eclaircissement Well, Gentlemen! Now I have seen you together, I'll go see how my dear Child does.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: So! God be thanked. Now I can let my fury fly. Sirrah! Rogue! Dogbolt, tho I bear something like this from my Nephew, who is such a Heathen as to make a jest of passive Obedience, shall I see my own Flesh rise in rebellion against me in my old age?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: But, Sir! Hear me a little.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I will hear nothing, you Rogue! To shew my Arbitrary power, I will execute first, and examine afterwards.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: But, Sir, Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Here's to decide the quarrel between us, you Rogue! And here's for the affront you put upon Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Sylvia? Rot me, I never saw her.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Sirrah, you lye! She says she will sooner espouse Infamy than you; and that an old paraly •• ck bedrid Beggar is a Prince to you. Then, Sirrah, here's for your talking insolently to your Father. And here's for your going like a Rogue by an alias. Mr Dorant, you Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: If I am a Son of a Whore, pray from whence do you take the priviledge of using me thus? and if I am a Son of a Whore • Gad, I don't know but Dorant may be likelier to • e my true name than Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Oh Rogue! Rogue! (Lifts up his stick again)

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Look you Sir, will you fairly hear me three words? If not, I shall fairly take up my heels and be gone.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Speak, Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Why then do you know that the young Lady who lies in your house to night, has taken a fancy to this Son of a Whore's person?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Which, I must confess, (aside.) I am amaz'd at. And therefore, Sirrah, you are asham'd of your Father and your Family?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: My Family? Why you assure me that I have reason enough to be • sham'd of my Mother, who is one part of my family, and as for my Father, till I know who he is, Rot me, I don't know whether I have reason to be asham'd of him or 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Here's a profligate villain! (lifts up his stick.)

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, one word more. Do you know that the old Countess has as great passion for quality, as her Daughter has for this Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: And is Bull a fit name for a Viscount's Son?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Well, I am a Cholorick old Coxcomb that is certain.

sp.speaker: Bull jun.
sp.p:
Look you, I had an opportunity of making you and my self. What I undertook was chiefly for your sake, but now I leave you to repent at le •
sure.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why, Batt!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: He bien!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nay, good Batt!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Vous p • aitil queque chose av •• moy?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Now 〈◊〉 this Rogue calling me names. (aside) Nay, dear Batt!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Juse a revoir

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nay, dear Batt. Tell me but one thing. Didst thou know this young Lady at Par • ?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: A pretty question! The Countess will resolve you. He bien! Serviteur.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nay, but Batt, why wilt thou be so obstinate?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: To prove my self legitimate.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Batt! here are fifty Guineas for thee and retrieve this business.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Well, for once! But S life, here comes the Countess. Come, come, off with your hat quickly, and shew the respect that is due to a person of my quality.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: I suppose by this time they may have consented to have carried this cheat on against themselves. So, Gentlemen, is the old difference like to be reconciled?

sp.speaker: Bell j.
sp.p: We are just upon the point, Madam. And you confess then (to his Father) that you are a testy petulent old fool?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I have been to blame in troth; was there ever such a Dog?

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: And that you have us'd your Son like a Beast?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Something too roughly!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: And you promise amendment?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: If he behaves himself for the future as you give me hopes.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Well! Put on your hat, put on your hat: Thou art a sad old scouudrel, but for this once I receive you to mercy.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (aside) Oh Rogue! Abominable Rogue! but I shall find a time.

div.stage: Enter Friskit with her Hoods and Scarfs.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Bless me! Whither is the Girl going?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Madam, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Whither away I say?

sp.speaker: Friskit.
sp.p: Madam, I am going to take. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: To take what?

sp.speaker: Frisk
sp.p: Only the air a little. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: It seems you are mightily tickled.

sp.speaker: Frisk
sp.p: I shall be, Madam, before I sleep. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Madam, I wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Jesu! Was there ever such a fond fool?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nature, Madam, Nature!

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: I thought, Sir, you had not know this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why, Faith, Madam, the pronuncing his name the French way, caus'd my mistake.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Well! I vow he's a fine person. Don't you think so?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why, truly, Madam, I think so, and my Son thinks so.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: At Paris, every body thought so.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: But here some ridiculous Rogues, swear he is come over a meer • op.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Envy and aversion to different customs! Ever while you live observe, that your Fop at London, is at Paris your fine Gentleman: But do you know the young Gentlemans • ather?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p:
What! My dearest friend? For tho the Vi •
count be my superiour quatenas Viscount, yet, in all things else, he does me the honour to esteem himself my equal. Faith and troth, Madam, there are few friendships like ours. I esteem no body throughly but him. And • tis thought, and perhaps with some justice, that he loves no body cordially besides my self.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Will you be so kind as to break this business to him?

sp.speaker: Bull s •
sp.p: Madam I will. Ill go down to his Seat in Northamptonshire, where I shall certainly find him, and about a month hence I'll give your Ladyship an account.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Jesu! Mr Bull, I must be in France long before that time.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: And your Ladyship has a mind to see this business dispatched before you go?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Do you think I would leave my dear Child in Convulsions?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: You are not over sollicitous you say, concerning the Jointure?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Not a jot.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why then, e'en let the young people take their course.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: What will the Father say to that?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Say? He • ll think the alliance an honour to him.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Will you answer for that.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I think I know him and I can govern him, I • ll answer for it.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Why then, as you say, e'en let the young people take their course.

div.stage: A great kn • eking is heard at the Door.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Hey day! Who should knock so imperiously Some body has mistaken my house for my Neighbour Midnight the Midwifes: Four or five times a week that happens to me, and my sleep like a Pandars is disturb'd for other Folks letchery.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, there are at the Gate half a score—

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why, Sir, surly, snarling, sowre look'd fellows.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: VVho are they?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why, at first, Sir, I thought they had been the club of ugly faces that is kept yonder in the City, and that they were come hither in a body to give your Worship an invitation.

sp.speaker: Bull s •
sp.p: Sirrah, I shall trepan your skull in good time But what would these fellows have?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: They come to look for a French Marquis who they say is newly come over.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And besides, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What besides, Sir?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Some Officers are searching Squire Grumbleton's house, by an order of Council, and threaten to be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Take that for your news, you Rascal. Do you hear that Madam? Half a score ill-look'd Rogues come to look for my Lord Marquis! And Officers just now coming to search my house? I must tell your Ladyship I don't like this: No, not a jot. This smells of Hemp, strongly, gadsbud, strongly.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p:
Lord! That I must tell you things twenty times over. Why, he comes mystically, Mr Bull, mystically, and where-ever they see him,
they'll least of all think of finding him. But heark, what noise is that.

div.stage: Enter Baldernoe, in a chair, Singing and whimsically drest. Three or four • iddles, before, and five or six persons dancing by the sides: He gets out of the Chair.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Chairmen! Take away your Shair presaunt; and Violons, attaund in de Anti-chambre.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Monsieur Le Marquis?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: My dear a Countess!

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: How over joy • d I am to see you again!

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Quese suis Ravi de vous trouver ici.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: (Who had been all this while holding up his, Hands and his Eyes, and marching up and down like one amaz • d.) And • is this he who is come over to be the chief manager of the Plot? Is this the great Politician? Bless us! What will become of me? Is this the great Politician? I • ll e'en try to slip my Neck out of the Collar, while it is time, and to save my self, we'll very fairly hang up the Marquis and the Countess. As he is • going

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p:
Meistre Bull •
Have you a forgot a me?

sp.speaker: Bull s •
sp.p: Forgot you! No gadsbud, I hant forgot you, for I never saw you before.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Ha! Meestre Bull You have too mush of de jugment to have de memoire. Me vas formerly here vid Barillon, and have receiv • d many good lettre de change of you Meestre Bull, and have had de ver mush frolick vid de money. De Francois have de ver great passion for de frolick, Meestre Bull, But me ver glad to see you Meestre Bull, ver glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I am sorry to see you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Jernie! Dat be de veritable, dam Eng • ish civil •• y.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p:
Why, gadsbud, I shall see your Lordship hang • d. Here are Politicks for the Devil? We shall
be infallibly found out: Did ever Politician appear in such an Equipage?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Ver well! Begad! Ver well! vee had de Anglish Civility before Now we have de veritable Anglish Politick: Because never Politick did appear in such an Equipage, derefore vee fall be infallibly found out. Mo • bleau, derefore vee sall infallibly not be found out.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I tell your Lordship we shall be all hang'd▪ The Officers are just now a coming to search the house. Look you, my Lord, I am downright, I am dunstable, Gadsbud▪ and must speak the truth. Did ever any man in a Conspiracy behave himself at your rate? Who the Devil would take you to be a Plotter?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Ver good again! Ver plaisant Begad! Who de Devil voud taken me for de Plotter? Who de Devil do desire to be taken for de Plotter? Not de Franc •• s, Meestre Bull: De English man do desire to be taken for de Plotter, and he is hang'd for de Plotter.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Well! I begin to think that I am an Ass, and that the Marquis is a wise man.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Madam La Comtesse!

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Have you yet spoke vid de Viconte?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Not yet, my Lord •

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p:
Do you know, Madam, dat de Duc has been vid me, and has meake me de promise to appear at de head of feeve tousand men! Meestre Bull, de Countess, Morbleau, be de brave Dame, and bea •
always about her de veritable marque of de voman of condition.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Pray what should that be?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p:
You must know dat in France de voman of
Condition be distingue from de common voman by de kisse.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud that's odd, as how pray?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p:
Look you Meestre Bull, Van in France you kiss de Dame upon de Mout, if she do stink of Brandevin, do you comprand me Meestre Bull, if she do stink very strong of Brandevin, Jernie dat be de ve ••
table voman of quality.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: And, Mr Bull, the men of quality in France too are distinguish'd by their savours.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Sometime, Mr Bull, sometime.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: As for example; the simple Gentleman smells modestly and you may approach if you please. The Chevalier stinks more proudly, and you must keep some distance. But the stately Marquis has an inaccessible hogo.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Diantre! Dat be plaisant De Countess, Meestre Bull be de Railleuse, De Countess be de • ver good Drole Meestre Bull.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, The Officers are come and want to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud, we are all undone, here are frolicks for the Devil!

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Meestre Bull, you have no apprehaunsion at all, no apprehaunsion of any thing, Meestre Bull. Stand a you still, and receive dem, and let me alone vid de reste. Allons, Violins, strike up de Minuet.

div.stage: The Musick plays a Minuet, The Officers enter during the Dance.

sp.speaker: 1st Of.
sp.p: Sir, We have an order of Council to search the Neighbourhood for persons who are in the Proclamation, but because we know you to be a civil Gentleman, we shall take your word. Is this all the Company that you have in your house?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: All, upon my word, Gentlemen •

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: Why then, we wish you a good night, Sir. For I'll swear these people are not in the Plot.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.p: He were a Devil who could take these to be Plotters.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Well, this Marquis is a great man.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Vat say you now, Meestre Bull? Vho vud taaka us to be de Plotters? Vat had become of you, if you had plotted vid de Anglish-man? Ven de Anglish man doe plot, Begad all his politiq be on de outside of him • and his Contenance be as terrible as if it vere already upon de Pole.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: His Lordship • s in the right of it. When an English-man goes about to cut a Throat, faith and troth he looks like a damn'd Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Ouy Morbleu! He appear to be de Felon, de Sauvage; he have de Devil of malice in his Visage. But van de Fraunch-man do go about to cut de troat, Oh de plaisant man! He be absolument de best humour'd Creature in de universal vorld: So civil, so frolic, so gay, dat dere be plaisir, dere be satisfaction in having de troat cut by de Fraunchman. Meestre Bull! Van de Fraunch-man do medite de grand mischief, he alvays copie dat bel original de Monkey; he show de ver plaisant grimace, he make de shattering and de noise, dat signifie just noting at all. Begad, you voud swear he had no meaning in the universal vorld: He dance up and down, and play de tousand pretty tricks, and begad do ruin twenty, forty, a hundred people, vile dey are making de ridicule upon him.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: His Lordship tells you but the naked truth.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Meestre Bull! you must put a your Scrawl to dis paper! (Pulling out a Pocket-book) Vat are you villing to contribute to de grand expedition?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What your Lordship thinks fit. But, my Lord, before I set my hand. (apart) would it not be convenient to send away these Dancing-masters?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Jernie! you take a dese Gentlemen to be de Coquin, de Maistre de Daunce? Dese be some of de plus grand personages de France, who be come over deguisee, to rendre service to your Nation: dis be Monsieur le Marquis De Coupee.

div.stage: (He presents them one after another, and Bull salutes them.)

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I am your Lordships most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Dis be de Viconte Baladin.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I am your honours most obedient.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: And dis be de Baron De Bellefigure.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Your very humble: If your Lordship will be pleas • d to let me see the Book, I'll set my hand to it.

sp.speaker: Bald
sp.p: (Looking in the Book) Barnaby Bull, a tousand pound! Very good, Meestre Bull, you sall have de ver good place for dat.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Officers who were here are come back with Mr. Bungy the Constable, who has assur'd them that there are suspicious persons in the house.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Damn'd Rogue!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I refus'd to open the doors till I had given notice of it.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Mr. Bull, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Ah, we sall do ver well, ver well begad. Madam la Countesse, let a me alone, and no aprehaund any ting. Run a you all (to those who are about him) and bring me de tings which I ordered to be left a in the Antichambre.

div.stage:
[They run and fetch disguises: Baldernoe disguises himself like a Constable, and his attendants like Watch-men. He
places himself on one side the door, and as Bungy and his attendants enter, Baldernoe lifts up his stick, and half knocks him down, and at the same time speaks.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Vho goe dere?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: (Returning the blow) A friend.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Vat friend? vat be your name?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: My name is Bungy, my name is pretty well known, friend.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Bungy! vich of de Bungy's? dere be Bungy de Cuckold, and Bungy de Vittal: Are you de Cuckol or de Vittal?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Hey day! what have we here? a Walloon Constable!

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Walloon! Jernie you lye in your troat, me be de ver good Gascon, and de high Conestable of Soho.

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: The high Constable of Soho! That, I must confess, may be, that may very well be indeed. But look you Brother Constable, here's an order of Council to search the house.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: My dear a Broder, me have already cherched the hoose, and me find just noting at all.

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: Have you look'd in the Cellar?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: There is nothing in the Cellar, upon my word Gentlemen, but two Pipes of Claret, and four Hogsheads of October.

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: Claret! That is French? Do you hear that my Boys? The Enemy's at hand, and in a strong body.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Fall on, fall on, fall on: Huzza! Huzza!

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: But hearkee, Brother. I have orders to take up every one that I find in this house, Officers only excepted. Now the thing that I would know of you, is, whether Mr Bull and that fat Gentlewoman are comprehended in that order.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: O • y Begad, dey are compraunded. Dat old man have de look, Brother, of de ver dam Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: Then some of you away with him, while I with the rest search the Cellar; for I shall not be satisfy'd till I see all the Vessels emptied, for fear there should be Gun-powder or Fire-arms hid there.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: But hearkee, Mr Constable, hear me a word.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Morbleu Broder, you no hearken to any ting; avay vid him presaunt.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Do you hear this, Madam? Dog of a Marquis!

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Mr Bull, he only does this for a blind, that he himself may pass unsuspected: For, he knows that you can receive no harm, unless they take up him, who has your hand-writing in his Pocket.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Humph! Gadsbud that's true. Well this is a wonderful man.

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: (to his followers.) Hearkee Gentlemen, what do you stay for? Away with them immediately.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Away with them! Away with them! Away with them!

div.stage: Some of them carry off Bull s. and Frowz.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: So! Now let's call in the Fiddles, and rejoyce for our good success.

lg.head: A Drinking Song by Mr Wycherley.
I.
lg.l: A Merry Cup, faith let us drink,
To be more wise the less we think,
Since thinking is a silly thing
Which brings us care,
Fear and despair,
To leave off thinking we should sing.

lg.head: II
lg.l: Well sing and drink eternally,
Who thinks too much, too soon will dye,
Too much thought, is too little sense;
He • s sad who thinks,
He's glad who drinks,
He who thinks least is most a Prince.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Wise Turks, that they may never think,
Take Opium, and wise Christians drink;
Thought drains and drys the fertile brain,
But moistning it,
Iudgment and Wit
Will flourish and spring up again.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: A merry Cup then let us take,
That dreams asleep, nor cares awake,
May break our rest, our peace destroy,
When we drink deep,
Cares, sorrows sleep,
Drowning our Care, buoys up our Ioy.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: The thinker is the greatest fool,
He without thought the true great soul,
Who lets the world jog on as 'twill,
Knowing all thought
Is good for nought,
But minds to torture, men to kill.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: So! Now Gentlemen, while you are drinking out the old fellow's Wine, I'll make use of my utmost art to terrifie him, that I may prepare him for what's to come.

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: But kearkee friend Joseph, thou who art a profest thorough-pac'd Rogue, hast appear'd as unconcern • d all this while, as if thou hadst been only acting. But I am sometimes ready to tremble, when I think what consequences this business may have.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: P'shew! If the worst comes to the worst, that which brought thee on will bring thee off.

sp.speaker: Bungy.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Why, your Landlord Belvil's Money, old Boy. But fear nothing, for 'twill be in our sham Plot, as 'tis often in real Conspiracies,

div.l: Where poor Rogues scape, who first the Plot being,
And the rich So • s are swing'd, who are drawn in.
div.trailer: The end of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE Old Bull's house.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: ANd what do I deserve now?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: A Statue: Thou art Mercu • y himself, the very genius and power of Cheating, and all the herd of Under-Rogues shall worship thee. But did my Cousin receive his Bride with so much joy?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: With Rapture.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Fools are most subject to little transports, because they are presently struck by appearances, and never reflect on consequences. But are you sure that neither my Cousin nor Friskit knew any thing of carrying away my Unkle?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: I am very sure. But what should oblige you to conceal it from Friskit?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Because at their return, I promise my self very good sport from their ignorance. About what time do you expect my Unkle back?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Much about this time. After that I Justice Baldernoe, had examin'd your Unkle and Frowzy, at my friend Mr. Palmer's house, and had commanded my Clerk to draw up their Mittimus, I told your Unkle, that to shew him what favour I could, he should have the priviledge of going in a Chair, and that Frowzy and his Guards should follow at a distance; so I ordered the Chairmen before they brought him hither to trot twice round the Garden with him, dismist the Myrmidons, threw off my disguise, and brought Frowzy along with me.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Are the Chairmen to be depended on?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p:
They are my Sub-pimps, and pick up a penny under me. But can you think to succeed in your attempt, of
making your Unkle's house pass upon him for Newgate?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Are you sure you ordered the Chairmen to bring him up to this very Chamber?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: I did. And trusty Joe, who acts the Jaylor, is planted at the door; with instructions to receive and guide them.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: This Chamber, you must know, is dignify'd by the name of the Devil's Apartment. It has been nail'd up these twenty years, upon the belief of its being haunted. And, besides, I have caus'd it to be disguis'd with as much art, as so short a warning would let me. But is my Unkle sufficiently scar'd?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Yes, damnably; and to terrifie him more, there happen'd the luckiest accident in the world. For just as the Chairmen were carrying him along, the Hawkers roar'd out a Proclamation just publish'd, for the apprehension of Conspirators who are just now discover'd, and I gave one of the Hawkers half a Crown to bellow out your Unkle's name; so that when he came to be examin'd, he never so much as look'd once up upon me. I never saw a more patibulary phyz: I'll tell you exactly for all the world how he look'd.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: How, prithee?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Did you never observe a fellow, who, while the house has been all on fire beneath him, has been measuring with his Eyes the leap from the Garret-window. Did you never observe such a one? Hah!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Why, Faith no—

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: Why then you never had the best diversion in the world. That would have given you an exact image of your Unkle.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Nay, at this rate we may make him believe what we please. But heark he comes, let us step in quickly.

div.stage: Enter Bull s. in a Chair, and Joe with a bunch of Keys in his hand, Bull s. gets out of the Chair, and the Chairmen take away the Chair.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Pray, Mr Keeper, let the Lady who follows me be well us'd.

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: She shall have all the favour I can shew her.

sp.speaker: • ull s.
sp.p: Have you never a better Room than this, Mr. Keeper?

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: Why, what ails the Room? A great many very good men have been hang'd out of this Room.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gads bud, what • commendation there was. Well! This is the only Jayl in Town that I have not yet been in. But I dont like coming to this Newgate a jot. As I came out of the Justices door to take Chair, I stumbled at the threshold and fell flat on my face? That was boding. Immediately my Nose burst out a bleeding. Another devilish omen? And to confirm both, news was immediately brought me that my Lord Marquis was taken in his Constables habit. Pray, Mr Jaylor, let me have Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: Do you design to impeach any one?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Sir, I design to write my Narrative, and pray don't be troublesom: My Narative! Good! Narrative Bull! This morning I had some little stock of reputation left in the world: And now before night I am turning Author and Evidence: Two very pretty creditable businesses.

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: May I ask whom you design to accuse, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Perhaps you, Sir. Pray friend don't be troublesom.

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: Me, Sir, I desie you, I am innocent, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Innocent, Sir! Well, Sir! And I am an Evidence, Sir. Look you, friend, I must produce Traytors to save my self, and Gadsbud I'll take the first persons I can light of: I • ll give my self as little trouble as I can.

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: Hark you Sir! If it were not for the Duty I owe Mr. Belvil, and the obligations I have to him, I would load you with Irons till you roar'd, for this.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why, do you know my Nephew Belvil, friend?

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: Know him? I think I have reason, Sir. He help'd me to the employment which I am in.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: He is one of those who stands bound to the Gentlemen who lent the Money which purchas'd it. He has just now sent to me, that in case you were committed—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, is this Prisoner nam'd Mr. Bull?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Friend, it is.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A Gentleman without desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ioe.
sp.p: Sir, before he can be admitted, I must go search and examine him.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p:
I am glad to hear that my Nephew has so much influence upon this fellow. Instead of Evidence, I shall now turn Suborner, and do what I can to corrupt the Jaylor. I'll send for my Nephew immediately, and to engage him closely in my interest, release my right of Guardianship, which by his Fathers Will was to continue till Marriage. What if I should likewise bestow his Mistress upon him? Humph! I'll do't: For sylv ••
refuses to marry my Son, and Batt will be better provided for.
Enter Rumour. Ah! my little Intelligencer!

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Bull, my heart bleeds to see this sight!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nay, prithee little Rumour, don't talk thus: Thou bringst the tears into my eyes. Prethee now what News, my Boy!

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nay, Gadsbud speak to me.

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Mr. Bull, I come from the Council-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: That damn'd Marquis! That damn'd Marquis!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Thou shrugst as much as if thou wert Dean of the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: That damn'd Marquis!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Has produc'd a Table-book—

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud I am a dead man.

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: You tremble and look pale, Mr. Bull. So glorious a Cause, and want resolution! What afraid, Mr. Bull?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: No, no, afraid! I am not afraid: But the noisome smell of the Jayl raises the Vapours, and will certainly suffocate me.

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Why, then I bring you comfort, comfort, Mr. Bull. Can you have patience till Friday?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why, what of Friday, little Rumour?

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Nay, all that you hear me say is, Can you have patience till Friday?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nay, but my dear Bully, give me some satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Before Friday night you'll be out.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: How dost thou know?

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Why they design to have you try'd to morrow, and hang'd before Friday noon. Have a little patience till Friday. Our friends, Mr. Bull, have great expectations from you, great expectations!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What expectations?

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Why, that you will go off bluff; and hang with such an air, with such a grace, that the Monthly Spectators at Hide-Park Corner may say unanimously, we were never so we • l pleas'd in our lives here.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: A pox please them! Dost thou hear any news of my son Batt?

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Your Son and the Countesses Daughter are both in the Proclamation: The Messengers are searching all over the Town for them. They have set a thousand pound a Head upon them.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Oh Nephew!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Ah Sir, I am throughly afflicted at this sight.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Are you here too, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Can you wonder at that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nephew! Thou wouldst be the most welcome man in the world to me, if I were not conscious to my self, that I have us'd thee so like a Rogue, that I am asham'd to look upon thee. Canst thou forgive me?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Can you be so good as to ask it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nephew, to shew you that I design to be a kind Unkle for the future, I here before this Gentleman release my right of Guardianship, both to you and to this Lady, and she may now dispose of her person and fortune, as she her self thinks fit.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Sir, you oblige me in the most sensible part of me: And before I have slept I shall endeavour to deserve this kindness.

sp.speaker: sylvia.
sp.p: It was but this afternoon, Sir, that you designed me for yo •• Son. This is a very sudden alteration.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p:
'Tis true, Mad • m. But other people now have a design upon 〈…〉 . Poor Ba ••
is like to 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Now, Madam, may I presume to claim the performance of your promise. What, no answer? But what answer could be so favourable to me as silence?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Nephew! Consider that the Halter is now about your Unkle's Neck. Some other time for Courtship good Nephew. The Jaylor gives me to understand that you have some influence over him.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Otherwise he were a very ungrateful Rogue. I have been just speaking to him in your behalf, and have with much ado prevail • d upon him—Heark you, Sir, a word in your ear. Who is that Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: A very honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Is he to be trusted?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: With any thing in the world • that he can't pawn. The Dog will entertain folks rather with his own invention, than with his friends secrets.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, with much ado, I have prevail'd upon the Keeper, to let you make your escape: But it must be upon his own terms.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Upon any terms, Gadsbud, upon any terms.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: You must know then, that so many who were committed for Treason, • having lately got out of this Prison, he lies under a strong suspition, and consequently must be oblig'd to make his escape with you, and to leave his employment.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Very good!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: This employment cost him three thousand pound, which is still a debt, and must be discharg'n before he goes off.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: It shall be paid to night.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And then two thousand pound will be the very least penny that can make compensation for his abandoning all, and provide for his subsistence in a foreign Country. Do you consent to the payment of that too?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud 'tis a great deal of Money.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, you have but a moment to resolve: For your Tryal comes on to morrow, and consequently your escape must be made to night: And if you determine to pay the Money, you must give your orders immediately.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: No abatement?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard, but I must submit: I have Notes for the money in my Pocket, which will be paid at sight.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: 'Tis very well! I will go and give all necessary orders and attend you agen. Madam, I wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Rum.
sp.p: Mr. Rull, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: This is a melancholy business in troth, a very melancholy business; but here comes Batt and the young Lady.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Hey day! What a Devil makes him in this Room, which has been nail'd up for these twenty years. Yesterday he was afraid to pass by the very door. Mr Bull your Servant.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Mr Dorant, your humble Servant. Madam, your most humble Servant. Are you two prisoners?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Prisoners! Ay, prisioners for life, old boy!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Perhaps not so neither.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: How, not so neither?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Bear up, don't be dejected.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I am always contented with my present condition, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Spoken, Gadsbud, like a wise woman.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: And for my part, I am both glad and proud of my captivity.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: This was always a vain Rogue, and always will be. Glad and proud of his being in Newgate! Senseless puppy, (aside) Who secur'd you?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Who secur'd you? How every old impertinent Fop can be satyrical upon a new married couple! Why, if you call it securing us, Parson Gogle secur'd us.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Did he so? He may be asham'd of the office.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (aside) What will this World come too? When a Parson is esteem • d the most contemptible Pandar, and marrying folks is thought the most scandalous sort of pimping; nay, and by such Reverend Grey-bearded Rogues too.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Who do you think did my business and the Countesses?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Why are you too in Limbo, to carry on the Allegory?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: In Limbo? Why what the Devil do you think I do here?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: (aside) In Limbo? Why what the Devil do you think I do here! A very odd answer! Very absurd, let me perish! Yet why should I wonder at that! When this was always an impertinent fellow: But who was it did you the blessed office?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why that treacherous Rogue my Neighbour Bungy, the Constable.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: My Neighbour Bungy?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Ay, Mr Dorant.

sp.speaker: • ull j.
sp.p: Bungy the Constable?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: That married you and the Countess? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Marry'd! Is that the cant word for sending a Man and a Woman together to this place?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: The Cant word for sending a Man and a Woman together to this place! (aside) Light headed by all that's good! Well! But if you and the Countess are link'd, I wish you joy, much joy of you Petters, Mr Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Look you Mr Dorrant, don't rally your friends in adversity, for that may breed ill blood: I give you fair warning.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: (aside) So! marriage has so far lost its credit, that it is christened adversity, and now adays, if you wi • h a married man joy, he immediately thinks you rally him.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Madam, this is a sad place for friends to meet in. I hope you'll excuse—

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Prithee honest Mr Bull, no Apologies, for she and I had as live see thee here, as in any place in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Let me tell you, the Press-yard is but a sad place to see a friend in.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: The Press-yard! Why who has any friend in the Press-yard?

sp.speaker: Bull • .
sp.p: Why is there no body in the Press-yard▪ whom you esteem your friend, and for whom you are conc • rn • d?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p:
Look you, between you and me, 〈◊〉
Bull I hope to see all the friends I have in the Press-yard, very fai • y hang • d

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (aside) Damn • d unnatural Rogue! Heark you! A word in your ear, Sir. Are not you a Dog to insult over your poor Father in affliction!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: In affliction!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (aside) Ay, Sirrah! when you too are in the same condition, and you • don't know what may become of you

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Become of me!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Ay Sirrah! As soon as I get out of this place, I shall remember this behaviour with a vengeance. 'Tis true indeed, I am now in a Jayl, and bound to my good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Ha! His Scull's crack'd, by Heavens.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: But I shall not be always in Newgate.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Stark staring mad, let me perish! (aside) Ha! I must humour his frenzy: For when he was sober, he would use me like a Football, if at any time I contradicted him: What will he do now he's mad?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I tell you, Sirrah, I shall have my liberty sooner than you may imagine.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Alas! I know it very well, Sir: The Keeper inform'd me of it as I came in but now.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: And how durst you say then, that you hop'd all would be hang'd that were in the Press-yard?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Lord Sir, I thought the Press-yard had been on the other side Newgate.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Oh! Did you so? Did the Keeper tell you how much I gave him?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: He said nothing of that.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Five thousand pound, you Dog! A swinging summ! But mum you Rogue! Gadsbud not a Syllable. Heark you, the Keeper makes his escape with me. But upon your life not a word!

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: This is very strange. He was well enough within this half hour, he talk'd as sensible as I my self can do: But these things will happen.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Don't be dismay'd, don't be dejected.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p:
Heark you my dear, in your Ear. Stark staring mad by Heavens: Humour him a little him in his Frenzy, while
I go fetch some to take care of him.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, you shall not be in Newgate three days longer, assure your self.

sp.speaker: Friskit.
sp.p: In Newgate, Sir! Lord! How wildly he looks!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: No, for if some people make good their promise to me, you may assure your self that the first thing I shall do after I have my liberty shall be to take care of yours.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I expect the appointed time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: As for my own part, I design for Flanders; but if I have any friends or interest in the world, I shall leave those behind me, who shall sollicit your business powerfully.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Well! this is very wild, and yet something consistent too. How do you find your self, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why, faith Madam, pretty well in Body, but grievously troubled in Mind. A troubled Spirit is a grievous burden, Madam. I am afraid I behave my self after a mad rate: But you'll have the goodness to excuse all.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: He seems something sensible of his condition; a sign that his case is not desperate.

div.stage: Enter Belvil, Bull j. Baldernoe, and Frowzy.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: (To the rest, who stop just by the Door) Look you, say as I do, and I • ll observe what you say: For, as you say, Ned, it is necessary that we should make him sensible of his condition, and cure him of this conceit of his being in Newgate.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: You must. For if, as you say, the fear of hanging has seiz'd so strongly upon him, as long as that continues, he'll grow worse.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: But then, Ned, for fear, as you say, that as soon as he is convinc'd that he is not in Newgate, he should grow unruly, and refuse to undergo the Remedies which may be proper for him; we must e • en make him believe, that he is in Salva Custodia in another place.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And that his friends who studied his welfare, made use of the Address of making him believe he was sent to Newgate, only that they might convey him gently to that other place

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Ay, ay, as Bedlam for example; but be sure you say as I do.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (spying them) Oh Nephew, where have you left your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: In a place where she has engagingly chang'd that name for a kinder.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (to Frowzy) Madam, I am sorry to see you here, I hope the Jaylor uses you kindly.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Jaylor! What Jaylor! Here's no Jaylor.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Where's no Jaylor?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Why not within a mile of this place.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Hey day! What! I warrant there's no Jaylor to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Newgate! Why there we have it again. Newgate! What Newgate? Rot me, here's no Newgate.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: This fool ought to be shut up in Bedlam,

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Why there's it, the fool is already shut up in Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What does the Fop mean?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Why the Fop has no meaning at all, and therefore he was sent hither. Look you old Gentleman, I will touch this matter as gently as I can to you. Your friends taking notice that you were grown something foolish, whimsical, absurd, and soforth, thought fit to have you sent to the Colledge here, that you might go through a course of Philosophy, and be cudgeli'd and firk'd into a little Wisdom, by the surly professors of this place.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: What can this Dog mean?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: But considering that you were always an obstinate Scoundrel, they thought it might be convenient to make use of a little Address with you. So taking you up for a sham Plot, they had you before a sham Magistrate, and instead of carrying you to Newgate, convey'd you to the Southside of Moorfields here.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Was ever such a hellish Rascal heard of?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Why look you, would any one but a Cit who was out of his Sences, call a person of my quality Rascal to my face!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: A person of your quality, you Rogue! Sirrah! What do I say or do like a mad man, that you dare to talk at this impudent rate to me?

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p:
Every thing tho • sayst or doest, let me perish. Will
you put it to the judgment of the Company: If thou canst give but so much as a reasonable answer to any thing; if thou either knowest what thou art, or where thou art, or with whom thou art, then will I be contented to be thought mad, and dieted and flogg'd in thy stead.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Say you so? Come on, Sir! I take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Come then, old Bully, answer to thy Catechism. What and where art thou?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Sirrah, to answer both in a breath, if I were not in Newgate, I would quickly prove to thee by very weighty arguments, that I am thy own natural Father.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Exceedingly foolish, let me perish. Come, come, judgment, judgment, the judgment of the Company. Is this old fellow in Newgate or in Bedlam?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: In Bedlam in Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Very good! Do you believe now that the inside of your Skull is a little out of repair, or no?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I am so amaz'd, that I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Oh, oh, are you thereabouts? Now, let only this Lady answer. Madam, (to Friskit) do you own this old fellow to be your Father or no?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Sirrah! Did I say I was her Father?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Sir, If you are his Father, you must be mine, for this is my Husband.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Is he so; I am glad of that however. (aside) Madam, he may be your Husband, but I'll make him know that he is my Son.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Raving mad, let me perish. Now Ned, do you answer: What is this old Gentleman's name?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Very good. And, Madam, (to Frowzy) what is my name?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Dorant.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: A Bethlemite, a Bethlemite, a Bethlemite!

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (to Frowzy) Tho his name is Dorant he is my Son. I shall satisfie your Ladyship about that business another time.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, who is that whom you call her Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Why the Countess there.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: The Countess! Ha, ha, ha, why that is Frowzy the Fla • derkin.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: The Countess! Ay, ay, this is Frowzy the Flanderkin! Well said little Ned, (aside to Belvil) banter him Ned.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And this is Friskit her Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: Ay, this is Friskit her Daughter. Ha, ha, ha. Well had ever man such diversion?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Well, either this (aside) old Countess is a damn'd Jade, or else it is a moot case, whether I am in Newgate or Bedlam. Frowzy, Have a care what you say, Nephew! she's a Bawd! This a Lady of Honour and Quality.

div.stage: Baldernoe, who had kept behind all this while, comes and stands before him, while Belvil says what follows, and stares him in the face.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: For my part, I won't say this Reverend Gentlewoman is a Bawd. But she's very famous for her Charity, I'll say that for her: A great doer of good offices, a reconciler of differences, and a promoter of Christian Union.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: (to Bald.) Oh, is your Lordship there? It seems you have accus'd me.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: (grinning) Do you speak to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Ha! Are not you my Lord Marquis?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.p: My Lord Marquis? Alas poor Gentleman! Let me see! (pulls out his Almanack) Full Moon March the first, three quarters after seven at night.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Why this is my man Baldernoe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Damnation! What do I hear? This is a Rogue. I both see him, and hear him, and smell him. Let me go, let me go, a plague confound you all, let me go

div.stage: They strive to hold him; he breaks from them and runs towards the Door.

sp.p:
Now let me see a little whither they have brought me whither this is Newgate or Bedlam. (He runs to the Door and looks out) Death and the Devil! I have been all this while in my own house. But tho I am not at present in Bedlam, I am not like to be long out of it. Was ever man serv'd as I have been? I have been us • d like a Bartholomew Cokes; I have been cheated of five thousand pound, have been made to pass for a mad man: And my Son in all likelihood is marry'd to the worst of Drabs. But hold, let me consider a little
That Fop there is my Son, and in affirming the contrary they are mistaken; and this is my own house: In saying it is not they lye. But that Rascal yonder is not a Marquis: So far they are in the right: Now what that old Gentlewoman and her Daughter are, it lies upon me to examin. For, tho my Son is an unnatural Rogue, yet I cannot wholly cast off the concern of a Father for him. Besides, both my Credit and Interest will suffer in his misfortune, and I am sure I must be concern'd for those, Madam!

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: And are you the very person that they say you are?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: The very person, at your service, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Bless us! And is it your Daughter that my Son has married?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Heav'ns! And is it your Son that my Daughter has married?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Am I thus grossly impos'd upon?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Am I thus basely cheated?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Is the Countess sunk to this?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Is the Viscount dwindled to this?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Have you that are a Bawd, and have known what Carting is, presume to marry your Daughter to the Son of such a man as I am?

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Have you that are a Cit, and have known what Cuckoldom is, dar'd to marry your Son, to the Daughter of such a Woman as I am?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud, the Boy's ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: Faith and troth the Girl's undone.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: He'll quite lose his Reputation.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: She'll be downright infamous.

sp.speaker: Bull s
sp.p: I design'd to make him one of the principal Merchants of England.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: I intended her for one of the topping Traders of the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: But he'll now be avoided by all substantial Dealers.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: She'll be now thrown off by all her lusty Lovers.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: As for my Daughter-in-law, I shall get her soundly whipt.

sp.speaker: Frowz.
sp.p: As for my Son-in-law, I shall get him fairly pillory'd.

sp.speaker: Bull j.
sp.p: (to Belv.) Hearkee Ned, prithee a word with thee: is all this rallery or no?

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Ral • ery you senseless puppy? Is this raillery? (strikes him) and this, and this. and this Nephew, a word or two with you.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: But without passion I beseech you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Without passion let it be then. Have you behav'd your self in all this business think you, suitably to the Character which you bear in the world? Where's the man of sense, and the man of honour in all this? Is it for a man of honour to be concern • d in a cheat? Or for a man of sense to bring misery and infamy upon his Family, and infamy too, which must reflect on himself. What is become of the money I gave you.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Why, to tell you the truth, I kept it as a Trustee for Collonel Medley.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Hah! Have you dar'd to do this? Gadsbud, I'll have you all indicted for Cheats.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Why then Baldernoe here shall e'en produce his pocket-book.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, it was agreed by Collonel Medley and me, that I should be serviceable to him in the getting his money for him, and he should be instrumental in the helping me to my Mistress; the Lady I have got, and he shall have the money.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: He shall?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: He shall. Yet to shew you that my intentions were honourable, and that in what I have done, I have acted by a nob • er motive than Interest, if you will promise before this Company to forgive what's part, and to approve my Marriage, then I promise upon the word of a Gentleman to pay back the five thousand pound, and to pay the same summ to the Collonel my friend, out of my own fortune.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Ha! Sayst thou so? And canst thou show • thy self so much a friend to one is of a contrary party?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p:
I can never cease to be a friend to any one, because he's in an unhappy errour. For to err is humane, and
whatever is humane may befal the best of us. I know the Collonel to be a man of honour, and men of honour in all parties have the noblest Relation.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Well, Nephew! To shew you that this generosity has touch'd me, set but that intreaging head upon invention once more, and find out a way to rid me of this Beldam, and her Daughter, so that I and my Son may never hear more of them, and the Town may never talk of the business, and I here promise not only to approve your Marriage, but to pay the five thousand pound to the Collonel my self immediately.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, know, that as you at the time that you fancied your self in Newgate, were very safe in your own house here, so your Son, tho he imagins himself link'd in Wedlock, is still the master of his Native freedom, and as a sham Magistate committed you to an imaginary Prison, so a counterfeit Priest betray'd him to a chimerical Marriage; and Baldernoe here, who was the Justice that committed you, was the Priest too who fetter • d your Son.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Gadsbud, let me hug him for it.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And now, Sir, I hope you are satisfy'd, that I have been so far from ingaging in a Cheat, that I have only oblig'd you to do justice to my self, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: I acknowledg it.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And instead of bringing misery and infamy upon my Family, I have endeavour'd, by opening your Eyes, to prevent your being cheated for the future, and consequently to prevent your real misfortunes, and your future Infamy. And first, for you, Cousin, I hope what has happen'd will something cool your passion for quality, which has so often run you into so many inconveniencies. For we have taken an effectual course, to shew you that a bare Title is but an imaginary excellence, which, though it sometimes shows and adorns true Merit, yet it never gives it, and does not always suppose it.

sp.speaker: Bull s.
sp.p: Sirrah! Lay this up in your heart.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p:
As for you, Sir, I have hopes that what is past, may somewhat assuage your itch of Caballing, and correct your Credulity. What has happen'd, may serve to convince you, that there are in all Parties, persons who find it their inte
• est
to deceive the rest, and that the one half of every faction, makes a property in Fee-simple of the other: Therefore, if I may presume to advise you, never believe any thing will or will not be, because it is agreeable or contrary to your humour, but because it is in it self likely or improbable. And that for the future, you may be secure from more dangerous attempts than mine, learn to check your Vanity, and to moderate that heat, which you show upon every occasion, and to humble your Pride. For credulity in men engaged in a party, proceeds oftner from Pride than Weakness. And it is the hardest thing in the world to impose upon an humble man.
sp.l: Few tricking Rogues would be believ'd,
Were acces • aries in the cheat,
And by themselves were first deceiv'd.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Spoken by Miss Alison, who acted the Beau.
div.l: THo I was lately slighted as a Beau,
I hope you • ll think me fit for business now.
For Friskit's motive to refuse me then,
Will scarce be thought a just one by the men.
For young and little things, are things, I'm sure,
Which you'll be well contented to endure.
Therefore the Poet was incli • 'd to chuse
Your humble Servant to sustain his Muse:
He knew, if I would beg, I should not want
A favour, who you know have one to grant.
I've kept it long; There's an old Dame—Pox on her,
An old morose, damn'd grinning Iade, call'd Honour;
Who with her coldness checks my forward Nature,
Else should I quickly prove—The happiest creature!
I'll throw her off, if possibly I can,
Throw the grim Goddess off, and put on Man.
I your young, bux • m Magdalen's despise,
She Saints, that have sev'n Devils in their •• es:
Who, to perswade us theyre above Humanity,
St • rve vigorous Appetites, to f • ed dull Vanity:
No; 'tis decreed, since Lovers are so plenty,
No Mai • shall tread • ur Stage of five and twenty.
I'gad we • ll use our prime, before tis past,
All won't find Legacies for being Chaste.
Now who shall 〈◊〉 he my ma • ? He, I swear,
Who for this Play most warmly shall declare:
The tis the empty • Fop in Covent-garden,
Nay, tho some wheezing o'regrown City Warden,
On whose high Front the Branching Antlers grow,
Full Beast above, and not half Man below.
